comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content: Noteworthy details: right-hand drive; acetylene headlights; smooth tread tires, decorative striping and clear coats of varnish on hand crank and chassis.

comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content:
technogeo--
Thanks for the details about this car and for pointing out the reflection of the photographer in the headlights.  We are always interested in pictures of photographers at work, and this is an unusual one!

comment.author: 46324377@N05
comment._content:
3 modes of transportation: walking, horse & carriage and the new fangled horseless carriage ;) 

My favorite part of the pic is the carriage & driver and his interaction with Mr. Bain, his glance at the spectacle on the street that was no doubt caused by the car and photographer. A great illustration of the rapid change taking place at the time. Fascinating.

comment.author: 70464403@N06
comment._content: I cannot beleive how sharp and clear this image is considering the circa it was shot...absoulty perfect

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
I see the lisense plate is a "DEALER" plate.

I don't now about New York, but here in Australia a DEALER plate is a license plate used by a car dealer to put on a new car while it is being test driven or until the new owner has had time to register it themself and obtain their own license plate.

comment.author: 17842909@N00
comment._content: Very interesting, the comparison of moving speeds -- walking, driving, and going in a carriage drawn by horses, which at this point is the fastest moving and is passing the car. That part of the description under the photo that says "[between ca. 1910 and ca. 1915] could be changed to "1914 or 1915", based on the 1914 date on the car license plate.
